reasoning: The critique targets an implied background picture that “moral diversity + compromise” operates in a roughly symmetric bargaining space, and argues that replication/bottleneck control will instead let some actor dominate, so the main failure mode is power rather than moral fussiness. This is only moderately central to the essay’s main thesis (“eutopia is a narrow target / value is fragile”), because (i) the paper’s core argument is about the moral-value landscape and the frequency of single-flaw catastrophes, not primarily about institutional bargaining equilibria (which it explicitly defers to the next essay), and (ii) power asymmetry arguably reinforces rather than undermines ‘no easy eutopia’ (it’s another dimension of fragility). Strength is limited because the critique mostly alleges an unmodeled mechanism and misframing; it doesn’t show that the paper’s key claims (multiplicativity, fussiness of plausible value functions, common-sense utopia falling far short) are false, and it leans on rhetoric (“naive”) more than concrete counter-models or demonstrations that the paper’s conclusions would change. Relevance is high: Forethought treats power concentration as a core risk and an active area of work, and the critique points to an interaction between flourishing/compromise narratives and political economy of replication/compute/space bottlenecks. Overall, it’s a useful redirect for adjacent work (esp. institutional design), but only a modest challenge to this essay as written.
title: The threat of power asymmetry, not just moral disagreement
